question.content: What is the scientific name of the banyan tree, a large evergreen tree of Asia characterised by its trunk-like aerial roots?

solution.content: Ficus benghalensis: Family Moraceae, Order Rosales, Kingdom- Plantae. Gossypium herbaceum: Levant cotton, Family Malvaceae, Order- Malvales. Santalum album: Indian Sandalwood, Family: Santalaceae, Order - Santalales. Ananas comosus: Pineapple, Family - Bromeliaceae, Order - Poales.

question.content: Match the columns. Column-A (Class) i.Chlorophyceae ii. Phaeophyceae Column-B (Common name) a. Brown algae (polysaccharide) produced from simple sugars using a fermentation process. Uses - common food additive, thickening agent, emulsifier, and stabiliser that prevents ingredients from separating.
What is the common term Ancylostoma?

solution.content: Hookworm. Ancylostoma is a genus of parasitic nematodes (roundworms) that primarily infect mammals. These worms are intestinal parasites and are transmitted to humans through contact with contaminated soil or sand where the larvae are present. Tapeworm: genus Taenia, Examples Taenia solium (pork tapeworm) and Taenia saginata (beef tapeworm). Filaria worms belong to the family Filarioidea.

question.content: Solanum lycopersicum L. is the scientific name of which of the following highly consumed vegetables?

options.text: Garlic b. Green algae c. Blue-green algae

solution.content: iv. Cyanophyceae d. Red algae iii. Rhodophyceae SSC CGL 14/07/2023 (1st shift) (a) i-b, ii-c, iii-a, iv-d (b) i-b, ii-a, iii-d, iv-c (c) i-d, ii-c, iii-b, iv-a (d) i-a, ii-b, iii-c, iv-d Sol.2.(b) i-b, ii-a, iii-d, iv-c. Divisions of Algae and their Main Characteristics: Chlorophyceae (Green algae): Major pigments Chlorophyll, Stored Food Starch, Example Spirogyra. Phaeophyceae (Brown algae): Pigment- fucoxanthin, Stored food Mannitol, Laminarin, Example Sargassum, Laminaria. Rhodophyceae (Red algae) : Pigment Phycoerythrin, Stored Food Floridean starch, Example - Gracilaria and Gelidium.

question.content: Which of the following is another name for starch found mainly in the pulp of seeds, fruits, tubers, roots and stems of plants, especially in corn, potatoes, wheat and rice?

solution.content: Amylum A polymeric carbohydrate consisting of numerous glucose units joined by glycosidic bonds. Olestra (Olean) Fat substitute that doesn't add any calories to products. Saponins They are naturally occurring compounds that are widely distributed in all cells of legume plants Xanthan Tomato. Potato - Solanum tuberosum, Onion Allium cepa, and Garlic - Allium sativum.

question.content: What is the common name Parthenium hysterophorus?

solution.content: Carrot Grass. Lemon grass Cymbopogon, Lawn Grass - Poaceae, Horsetails - Equisetum.

question.content: Oleo gum resin (Asafoetida) can obtained from:

options.text: dried latex from the stem of ferula
dried latex from the roots of mango tree of be
dried latex from the banana leaves
dried latex from the tap root of ferula

answer: dried latex from the tap root of ferula

solution.content: Oleo-gum-resin (Asafoetida) can be obtained from the exudates of the roots of the Iranian endemic medicinal plant, Ferula asafoetida. It has cytotoxic, antiulcer, anti-neoplasm, anti-cancer, and anti-oxidative effects.

question.content: The scientific name for the domestic _ is Canis lupus familiaris.

solution.content: Dog. Bubalus bubalis Buffalo, Felis catus - Cat Bos taurus - Cow

question.content: What mango? is the botanical name of

solution.content: Mangifera indica. Botanical Names: Cocos nucifera (Coconut), Monoon longifolium (False Ashoka), Saraca asoca (Ashoka tree), Casuarina (Australian pine). Nutrition in Animals

question.content: Select the INCORRECT statement with regards to vitamins. SSC CHSL Tier Il 02/11/2023

options.text: Plants can synthesise almost all vitamins.
Some bacteria in the gut do not produce vitamins.
Most of the vitamins cannot get synthesised in sufficient amounts in our body.

answer: Some bacteria in the gut do not produce vitamins.

solution.content: Gut bacteria helps in supplying essential nutrients, synthesising vitamin K, aiding in the digestion of cellulose. Vitamins A, D, E and K are fat-soluble and vitamins C and B (complex group vitamins) are water- soluble.

question.content: Which essential micronutrient plays a clear role in the synthesis, storage and secretion of insulin in the hexameric form as well as in the conformational integrity of insulin?

solution.content: Zinc. Micronutrients are vitamins and minerals needed by the body in very small amounts. Role of some micronutrients in our body: Fluoride inhibits the initiation and progression of dental caries (tooth decay) and stimulates new bone formation. Selenium (Se) plays a critical role in reproduction, thyroid hormone metabolism, DNA synthesis, and protection from oxidative damage and infection. Phosphorus is a component of bones, teeth, DNA, and RNA.

question.content: Which of the following was the first B vitamin discovered in 1897 that is essential in amino acid and carbohydrate metabolism and is active in energy production reactions?

solution.content: Thiamine. Casimir Funk is considered as the 'Father of vitamin therapy'. Vitamin B: B, (thiamin), B2 (riboflavin), B3 (niacin), B (pantothenic acid), B6 (pyridoxine), B, (biotin), B, (folic acid), B12 (cobalamin). Fat-soluble Vitamins: A, D, E, and K. Water-Soluble Vitamins B and С.

question.content: What is the most important health benefit of Vitamin D?

solution.content: Vitamin D (Calciferol): Source - Oily fish, egg yolks, red meat, etc. Deficiency Diseases - Rickets. Symptoms weak and painful bones, Deformities in teeth, Pain in the bones.

question.content: The food component present in sugar is:

solution.content: Carbohydrates. Sugar molecules found in foods and drinks. The body breaks down carbohydrates into glucose (main source of energy for the body). Source Breads, beans, milk, popcorn, potatoes, cookies, spaghetti, soft drinks, corn, etc. Vitamins - Group of substances that are needed for normal cell function, growth, and development. Proteins are made up of amino acids.

question.content: Milk, seafood, nuts and whole grains contain high amounts of which mineral that supports bone health and our body's repair process?

solution.content: Phosphorus. Other Minerals found in Milk: Calcium, Magnesium, Potassium, Selenium and Zinc. Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) is absent in Milk. Minerals and their sources: Iron Spinach, dry nuts and seeds, Legumes (chickpeas and lentils). Zinc - Pumpkin seeds, Eggs, Whole Grains.

question.content: Which of the following vitamins prevents major birth defects of the brain and spine of a newborn baby?

solution.content: Folic Acid (Vitamin B9): It helps to prevent and cure low levels of folates. Folates play an important role in forming red blood cells and maintaining brain health. Sources Dark green leafy vegetables, beans, peanuts, fruits, whole grains.

question.content: Carbohydrates are utilised by the human body in the form of:

solution.content: Glucose The main type of sugar in the blood and is the major source of energy for the body's cells. A nucleotide is the basic building block of nucleic acids {RNA (Ribonucleic acid) and DNA (Deoxyribonucleic acid)}. Fibre is a type of carbohydrate that the body can't digest. Amino acids are organic compounds that contain both amino and carboxylic acid functional groups; Break down food, Grow and repair body tissue, Make hormones and brain chemicals.

question.content: What is the monomer unit of glycogen?

solution.content: Glucose (CcH2O). Glycogen The carbohydrates are stored in the animal body as glycogen. Also known as animal starch because its structure is similar to amylopectin and is rather more highly branched. It is present in the liver, muscles and brain. When the body needs glucose, enzymes break the glycogen down to glucose. Found in yeast and fungi. Fructose It is a natural monosaccharide found in fruits, honey and vegetables.

question.content: Which vitamin is synthesized in the presence of sunlight in our body?

solution.content: Vitamin D: Sources - sunlight, oily fish, milk. Deficiency disease Rickets (bone become soft). Vitamin and Sources Vitamin A: Source Milk, butter, cheese, Cod liver oil, Green leafy vegetables. Deficiency disease Night blindness. Vitamin B: Source - Fish Eggs, Dairy Products, Green vegetables. Deficiency diseases - Beri beri. Vitamin C Source Citrus (oranges, kiwi, lemon, grapefruit), Tomatoes, Strawberries. Deficiency disease - Scurvy (gums swell and bleed).

question.content: Which essential amino acid is necessary for the production of our brain's chemical messengers including melatonin, dopamine, noradrenaline and thyroxine?

solution.content: Phenylalanine is an essential amino acid to make proteins and other vital molecules such as neurotransmitters and hormones. Leucine amino acids can be used by skeletal muscle to give energy during exercise. Tryptophan is an amino acid needed for normal growth in infants and for the production and maintenance of the body's proteins, muscles, enzymes, and neurotransmitters.

question.content: Which of the following is the correct match of column-В? Column-A (Nutrients) i. Protein rich food. ii. Fat rich food iii. Carbohydrate rich food iv. Vitamin C rich food column-A with Column-B (Source) a. Wheat b. Lemon c. Egg white d. Butter and cheese

solution.content: i-c, ii-d, iii-a, iv-b. Important Nutrients in Food and their functions : Carbohydrates - One of the main sources of energy for human beings. Three types of carbohydrates in food Fiber, Sugar, and Starch. Iron- It is a constituent of our red blood cells whose function is to carry oxygen from our lungs to organs, muscles, and cells.

question.content: Vitamins and minerals are helpful for which of the following?

options.text: Carry out metabolic reactions in our body

answer: Carry out metabolic reactions in our body

solution.content: Vitamins and their sources: Vitamin A - Milk, egg. Vitamin D - Cheese, butter, milk. Vitamin E Vegetable oils, lettuce, turnip leaves. Vitamin K spinach and soybeans. Vitamin B- Seafood, milk, meat, peas. Minerals and their sources: Iron Meat, fish, liver, eggs, turnip, germinating wheat grains and yeast. Calcium Milk. Phosphorus Meat, egg, fish, whole grains. Q.23 As per the dietary guidelines recommended by doctors, the RDA for cholesterol intake in healthy adults and children above four years of age is _ mg/day. SSC CGL 25/07/2023(2nd shift) (a) 400 (b) 600 (c) 500 (d) 300 Sol.23.(d) 300. Cholesterol A waxy substance found in the blood. The body needs cholesterol to build healthy cells. It comes from two sources: The liver and foods from animals (meat, poultry and dairy products). A high level of cholesterol can develop fatty deposits in the blood vessels.

question.content: Which water-soluble vitamin found in various foods, including liver, milk, eggs and fish, helps to keep your body's blood and nerve cells healthy?

solution.content: Vitamin B12 (cobalamin). Sources -Meat, Fish, eggs, and dairy products. It helps in forming RBC. Deficiency of this vitamin causes symptoms like tingling in the tongue, anemia, white patches on the skin, mouth ulcers and shortness of breath.

question.content: Which of the following vitamins helps to keep our skin and eyes healthy?

solution.content: Vitamin A. Deficiency Diseases Night blindness, Irregular growth of teeth.

question.content: Which among the following vitamins influences iron absorption?

solution.content: Vitamin C (Water soluble). Scientific name: Ascorbic acid (CHO) or ascorbate. It acts as an antioxidant and helps wound healing. It also helps in the formation of collagen. It is used to purify water after it has been lodine-treated.

question.content: Which of the following vitamins helps our body to use calcium for bones and teeth?

solution.content: Vitamin D (Calciferol) - It helps prevent Osteoporosis (a disease that thins and weakens the bones and makes them brittle and more likely to break). Source Oily fish, egg yolks, red meat, etc.

question.content: Which of the following pairs of 'mineral - source' is correct? I. Vitamin A - Papaya II. Iron - Spinach

solution.content: Both I and II. Vitamin A - Milk, Eggs, Fish, Butter, Fortified Margarine, Cheese, Green & Yellow fruits and Vegetables, etc. Vitamin E Meats, Poultry, Eggs, Vegetable oils, Nuts, Olives, Tomatoes, etc. Zinc - Liver, Eggs, Cereals and Seafood.

question.content: Which among the following Vitamins is known as Niacin?

solution.content: Vitamin B3. Niacin is the generic name for nicotinic acid (pyridine - 3-carboxylic acid), nicotinamide (niacinamide or pyridin-3-carboxamide).

question.content: Which among the following is a fat soluble vitamin?

solution.content: Vitamin D promotes calcium absorption in the intestine and maintains adequate serum calcium and phosphate concentrations to enable normal bone mineralization and to prevent hypocalcemic tetany (involuntary contraction of muscles, leading to cramps and spasms).

question.content: Match the columns. Nutrients a. Protein b. Carbohydrate c. Fat d. Minerals Examples i. Calcium, Phosphorous ii. Cholesterol iii. Glucose iv. Myosin SSC CGL Tier II (07/03/2023)

solution.content: a-iv, b-iii, c-ii, d-i. Carbohydrate: It consists of sugar, starch, and fiber. Two types Simple Carbohydrates (Monosaccharides, Disaccharides, Oligosaccharides) and Complex Carbohydrate. Fat It is a macronutrient essential for energy storage, insulation, and the absorption of certain vitamins.

question.content: Match Column-A with Column-В. Column-A (Vitamin) i. Vitamin A ii. Vitamin B12 iii. Vitamin C iv. Vitamin D Alternative Name a. Ascorbic b. Retinol c. Cobalamin d. Ergocalciferol (Shift - 3)

solution.content: i-b, ii-c, iii,-a, iv-d.

question.content: Which of the following statements is correct? I. The nutrition requirements of adolescents are higher than adults. II. Adolescents are generally grouped in the age group of 10 to 19 years.

solution.content: Both I and II. Adolescence is the period of transition between childhood and adulthood and is a crucial developmental stage for our mental well-being.

question.content: Which of the following pairs (type of nutrient - nutrient) is correct? I. Macronutrient - Iron II. Micronutrient - Calcium

solution.content: Only II. Macronutrients : Carbohydrates, Fats, calcium and Proteins. Micronutrients : Boron (B), Chlorine (CI), Copper (Cu), Iron (Fe), Manganese (Mn), Molybdenum (Mo), Zinc (Zn) and Nickel (Ni). Calcium is the most abundant mineral in the body with 99% found in teeth and bone.

question.content: Nuts, vegetable oil and fish are rich sources of

solution.content: Omega-3. Most common forms of carbohydrates are sugars, fibers and starches. Minerals which are essential for health : iron, calcium, magnesium, zinc, potassium etc.

question.content: Which of the following pairs of minerals - need is correct? 1. Iron - formation of hemoglobin II. Sodium - proper functioning of thyroid

solution.content: Only I. lodine is needed to make a hormone called thyroxine. Biological Importance of Sodium: For the generation of nerve impulses, For maintenance of electrolyte balance and fluid balance, For heart activities and certain metabolic functions.

question.content: Which of the following vitamins is absent in eggs?

solution.content: Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) is found in citrus fruit (oranges), peppers, strawberries, blackcurrants, broccoli, brussels sprouts, potatoes etc.

question.content: Which amino acid is essential for healthy skin and teeth, as it is a component of tooth enamel, collagen and elastin?

solution.content: Threonine used in the biosynthesis of proteins. Leucine is an essential amino acid for protein synthesis. Arginine is used for the treatment of heart and blood vessel conditions including congestive heart failure (CHF), chest pain, high blood pressure, etc. Phenylalanine is used for a disorder that causes white patches to develop on the skin (vitiligo).

question.content: Which of the following is a micronutrient, and plays a role in cell division, cell growth, wound healing and the breakdown of carbohydrates?

solution.content: Zn. Functions of Macronutrients in Plants: Nitrogen (required in large amounts, taken in the form of ions, required for the division of cells), Phosphorus (a constituent of cell membranes), Magnesium (involved in the activation of enzymes in respiration and photosynthesis and helps in the synthesis of DNA and RNA), Sulfur (an important constituent of amino acids, coenzymes, and vitamins), Potassium (required for the opening and closing of stomata).

question.content: Which vitamins are present in Milk?

solution.content: Vitamin A, B and D. Milk is a good source of thiamine, riboflavin and cobalamin. It contains the fat soluble vitamins A, D, E, and K.

question.content: Match column A With column B. Column - A (Vitamin) i. Vitamin A ii. Vitamin B iii. Vitamin C a Column - В (Source) Carrot, mango, papaya b. Whole grain bread and nuts c. Citrus fruits, red and green pepper iv. Vitamin D d. Egg yolk, soya product

solution.content: i - a, ii - b, iii- c, iv - d.

question.content: What components are often called the building blocks of the body that play a vital role in helping to repair and strengthen muscle tissues after exercise?

solution.content: Proteins. Three important building blocks of the body are amino acids, lipids, and nucleotides. Uses: development of muscles and organs, production of hormones and antibodies, storage of fat, and production of energy.

question.content: Which is a major essential lipophilic (fat-soluble) vitamin required for the protection of cell membranes and the formation of red blood cells (RBCs)?

solution.content: Vitamin E (Tocopherol) is a nutrient that's important to vision, reproduction, and the health of blood, brain and skin.

question.content: A typical adult human body contains about of magnesium.

solution.content: 25 g. Magnesium is required for the proper growth and maintenance of bones. Magnesium helps keep blood pressure normal, bones strong, and the heart rhythm steady.

question.content: Starch and sugar in our food are forms of_

solution.content: Carbohydrates are the main source of energy for the body. They are sugars, starches and dietary fibers that are found in plant foods and dairy products.

question.content: When the breakdown of food (glucose) occurs without the use of oxygen, it is called:

solution.content: Anaerobic respiration. Aerobic respiration The process by which organisms use oxygen to turn fuel, such as fats and sugars, into chemical energy. Cellular respiration The process by which organisms combine oxygen with foodstuff molecules. Capillary respiration Blood from the heart flows through these capillaries and collects oxygen from the alveoli.

question.content: Which organism among the following breaks down the food material outside the body and then absorbs it?

solution.content: Yeast. Mushroom, Yeast, and Bread mould are saprophytic. They break down food outside the body and absorb the simpler digested particles.

question.content: From which of the following sources does the brain get energy?

solution.content: Glucose. Glucose is oxidised through glycolysis and oxidative phosphorylation to produce ATP by mitochondria. Nutrition in Plants

question.content: Which natural bioactive water-soluble phenolic compound is present in Fruits, vegetables and grains with red, purple, blue or black hues?

solution.content: Anthocyanin (Pigment found in plants). They're part of a larger category of plant-based chemicals called flavonoids. Foods with high anthocyanin : Fruits Pomegranates, Black plums, Cherries, black and red grapes etc; Vegetables Red cabbage, Red onions, Purple corn etc; Legumes and Rice - Black rice, Black beans etc. Coumarins colourless crystalline solid, sweet odor, bitter taste. Quercetin - bitter flavor, used in dietary supplements, beverages and foods. Naringenin Anti-obesity, anti-diabetic flavonoid.

question.content: Which of the following nutrients is available mainly in apples?

solution.content: K Potassium-rich fruits and vegetables: Bananas, oranges, cantaloupe, apricots, grapefruit (some dried fruits, such as prunes, raisins, and dates, are also high in potassium). Malic acid: Found primarily in apples. It is a dicarboxylic acid that is also present in grapes, wine and rhubarb.

question.content: Which of the following grains contain oryzenin?

solution.content: Rice A source of protein and contains various vitamins, such as thiamin and niacin, and minerals, such as zinc and phosphorus. Oryzenin - A rice glutelin, is an important constituent of rice protein. Glutelin comprises the major protein fraction of the rice grain and constitutes up to 80% of the total protein. Wheat contains protein, B vitamins, dietary fiber, and phytochemicals. Soyabean is high in protein and contains vitamin K1, folate, copper, manganese, phosphorus, and thiamine.

question.content: What happens to the guard cells when water flows into them?

solution.content: Stomatal pores open. Guard cells - They are specialized plant cells in the epidermis of leaves, stems and other organs that are used to control gas exchange. It is a kidney shaped cell that surrounds the stomata. It contains chloroplasts, which are not present in other epidermal cells. Function - To open and close the stomata, help regulate transpiration, and protect the stomatal pore.

question.content: Plants that are adapted to live under plenty of sunlight are called:

solution.content: Heliophytes. Examples- Sunflowers, thyme, white clover, soft velcro, mullein. Xerophytes - A group of plants that are adapted to survive in arid regions like desert and snow covered areas. Example Cacti, pineapple. Pteridophytes - That plants have a vascular system and reproduce through spores. Example Whisk Fern, Dicksonia, Selaginella. Neophytes Plant which is not native to a geographical region and was introduced in recent history. Example Sweet flag, small balsam, cranberries.

question.content: The leaves have a green pigment called _,which helps leaves to capture the energy from the sunlight.

solution.content: Chlorophyll - Element present in chlorophyll is magnesium. Cytoplasm - The fluid inside the cell. It functions as a cellular metabolism, transport, and storage medium while providing structural support and facilitating signal transduction within the cell. Cladophyll Shoot system in which leaves do not develop. Xanthophylls are yellow pigments that are one of the important divisions of the carotenoid group.

question.content: Which plant tissue is responsible for the transportation of water and minerals from the soil to the stems and leaves?

solution.content: Xylem. Xylem and phloem are the two vascular tissues that are responsible for the transport of substances in plants. Phloem helps in the bidirectional transport of food.

question.content: Which of the following is the ultimate source of energy for all living organisms?

solution.content: Sun. The Sun is the primary source of energy for all ecosystems. In the terrestrial ecosystem Autotrophs (plants) get energy from sunlight and provide food → Herbivores (goat) Carnivores (tiger). In aquatic ecosystems Phytoplankton get energy from sunlight and provide food → zooplankton → fishes.

question.content: The mode of nutrition in which organisms make food themselves from simple substances is called

solution.content: Autotrophic nutrition. Examples Plants, algae and some bacterias. Heterotrophic nutrition Depends upon plants or other organisms for nutrition. Examples Humans, animals, Cuscuta (Amarbel). Saprotrophic nutrition This mode of nutrition in which organisms take in nutrients from dead and decaying matter. Examples Fungi, yeast, and several bacteria. Phototrophic nutrition Organisms that can obtain nutrition using light. Examples Green plants, blue-green algae.

question.content: Plants require nutrients for their growth which can be supplied through

solution.content: Soil, water and air. Three elements (carbon, oxygen and hydrogen) are essential to plant growth. Soil Supplies not only minerals but also harbours nitrogen fixing bacteria, and other microbes, holds water, supplies air to the roots and acts as a matrix that stabilises the plant.

question.content: Water comes out of the leaves in the form of vapour by a process called

solution.content: Transpiration. Three types of Transpiration: Stomatal transpiration - Evaporation of water through stomata. Lenticular Transpiration - Evaporation of water through lenticels (small minute openings present on the stem), Cuticular Transpiration Loss of water from the cuticle (waxy layer on the surface of leaves).

question.content: The broad, green part of the leaf is called

solution.content: Lamina. The venation of leaves is the process of arrangement of veins and veinlets. Veins carry deoxygenated blood from the body's tissues back to the heart for reoxygenation. They are crucial for both systemic and pulmonary circulation. The middle part of the vein of lamina is called the midrib. Petiole (mesopodium) Lifts the lamina above the level of the stem.

question.content: The green plants in a terrestrial ecosystem capture about percent of the energy of sunlight that falls on their leaves and convert it into food energy.

solution.content: 1. Photosynthesis is the process by which green plants produce carbohydrates by absorbing carbon dioxide, water, and sunlight in the presence of chlorophyll and liberating chemical energy. This energy is converted into chemical energy as food.

question.content: Nuts, vegetable oil and fish are good sources of which of the following?

solution.content: Healthy fats. Monounsaturated fats and polyunsaturated fats are known as the "good fats" because they are good for heart, cholesterol, and overall health.

question.content: Which nutrient is chlorella rich in?

solution.content: Protein. Chlorella is known as space alga. It is used for the consumption of carbon dioxide provided by the astronauts and the production of oxygen in the spacecraft.

question.content: Iron, iodine and zinc can be considered as which of the following?

solution.content: Micronutrients are nutrients that are required by the body in lesser amounts for its growth and development. Examples Magnesium, vitamin B6, vitamin C, vitamin E, etc. Non-essential nutrients can be synthesized in the body in sufficient quantities for normal functioning. They can be obtained from food as well. Examples : Alanine, Arginine, Asparagine, Aspartic acid, etc.

question.content: Starches found in breads, cereals and pasta are made up of long chains of

solution.content: Glucose. Carbohydrates are essential macronutrients which include sugars, fibers and starches. There are six types of sugar (C6H120): Glucose, Fructose, Galactose, Lactose, Maltose, Sucrose. Starch is a polymeric carbohydrate that is composed of numerous glucose monomers.

question.content: Which of the following pairs of plastids- thing stored is NOT correct? I. Amyloplasts - oils and fats II. Aleuroplasts - carbohydrates

solution.content: Plastids are found in plants and algae. Functions perform photosynthesis, attract pollinators, restore total leaf protein and synthesize starch along with the storage of proteins, fats, and oils. Types of Plastids Chloroplasts (used for photosynthesis), Chromoplasts (used for pigment synthesis and storage), and Leucoplasts (non-pigmented plastids that can sometimes differentiate).

question.content: How is food stored in brown algae?

options.text: In the form of complex carbohydrates that may be in the form of laminarin or mannitol.
In the form of complex lipids
In the form of oil droplets

answer: In the form of complex carbohydrates that may be in the form of laminarin or mannitol.

solution.content: In the form of complex carbohydrates that may be in the form of laminarin or mannitol.

question.content: Pneumatophores are specialised _ in hydrophytes.

solution.content: Roots. Hydrophytes are aquatic plants that are especially suited for living in aquatic environments. Examples Lotus (Nelumbo), Vallisneria, Potamogeton, Salvinia, hydrilla, water hyacinths etc.

question.content: At least of the carbon dioxide fixation on earth is carried out by algae through photosynthesis.

solution.content: a half. Jan Ingenhousz is known for his discovery of photosynthesis and as the 'father of photosynthesis'.

question.content: Capsaicinoids, carotenoids, phenolics, and vitamins are dominant chemicals in which of the following foods?

solution.content: Chilli. Caffeic acid is the predominant phenolic acid in carrots. Allicin chemical gives flavour to garlic. Four major organic acids are present in the roots of the radish: oxalic, malic, malonic, and erythorbic acid.

question.content: Which of the following is an essential element used in the synthesis of proteins in plants?

solution.content: Nitrogen. Plants are not capable of producing nitrogen, therefore, plants obtain nitrogen with the help of nitrogen-fixing bacteria like Rhizobium.

question.content: The_ is the term used for the reactions of photosynthesis that use the energy stored by the light-dependent reactions to form glucose and other carbohydrate molecules.

solution.content: Calvin cycle.

question.content: Energy and carbon requirements of the autotrophic organism are fulfilled by

solution.content: Photosynthesis. Lysis refers to the breakdown of a cell caused by damage to its plasma (outer) membrane. Prognosis is the likely outcome or course of a disease; the chance of recovery or recurrence. Glycolysis is the process in which glucose is broken down to produce energy.

question.content: Which of the following does NOT figure among the main functions of the root system of a plant?

options.text: Supply of food to plant parts
Providing a proper anchorage to the plant parts
Absorption of water from the soil
Absorption of minerals from the soil

answer: Supply of food to plant parts

solution.content: Supply of food to the plant parts. The main function of the root system is to transport water and minerals to the plant. Food is transported by phloem tissue in the vascular system of plants.

question.content: Which of the following plant hormones regulates growth, particularly by stimulating cell elongation in stems?

solution.content: Auxin. Ethylene is the only plant hormone in gaseous form that regulates fruit ripening in plants. Cytokinin promotes cell division in plant roots and shoots. Gibberellin regulates various developmental processes, including germination, dormancy, flowering, flower development, and leaf and fruit senescence.

question.content: The application of plant and soil science to crop production is known as

solution.content: Agronomy. Agrostology - It is the branch of botany concerned with grasses. Bryology It is the branch of botany concerned with the scientific study of bryophytes. Anatomy - It is the science that studies the structure of the body and body parts.

question.content: Which of the following gases is released in the process of photosynthesis?

solution.content: Oxygen. In the presence of sunlight, Carbon dioxide + water Carbohydrate + oxygen. Plants, green algae, and cyanobacteria can perform photosynthesis. Deficiency and Diseases

question.content: Severe undernutrition due to the deficiency of food and energy is termed as SSC CHSL Tier II 10/01/2024

solution.content: Marasmus It occurs both in children and adults. Wasting - It is a type of undernutrition that causes low weight for height. Dementia It is the group of symptoms used to describe impaired ability to remember, think, or make decisions. Alzheimer's disease is the most common type of dementia.

question.content: Deficiency of iodine results in an insufficient amount of the _ hormone. SSC CHSL Tier II 02/11/2023

solution.content: Thyroid. lodine deficiency is the most common cause of thyroid disease. Some diseases/ disorders caused by Deficiency of vitamins and minerals: Loss of vision Vitamin А, Beriberi - Vitamin B1, Scurvy vitaminC, Rickets Vitamin D, Bone and tooth decay - calcium, Anaemia - Iron.

question.content: Among the choices listed, which one is NOT a form of cancer? SSC CGL Tier II 26/10/2023

solution.content: Glaucoma A group of eye diseases that can cause vision loss and blindness by damaging a nerve in the back of your eye called the optic nerve. Carcinoma Cancer that starts in tissue lining your skin, organs and internal passageways in your body. Lymphoma Cancer that begins in cells of the lymph system. Sarcoma - Cancers that begin in the bones and in the soft (also called connective) tissues (soft tissue sarcoma).

question.content: Among the following diseases, which one is NOT inherited? SSC CGL Tier II 26/10/2023

solution.content: Malaria - Caused by parasites that are transmitted to people through the bites of infected female Anopheles mosquitoes. question.content: Which of the following is NOT an example of "viviparous" animals?

Examples - Dolphin, Whales, Humans, Cat, Elephant, Dogs, Cow. Oviparous Animals that lay Eggs which can be either fertilised or unfertilised. Examples - Birds, lizards, frogs, chickens, alligators, snakes, crocodiles, fishes, etc.

question.content: The transformation of the larva into an adult through drastic change is called

solution.content: Metamorphosis - A biological process involving an abrupt change in the animal's body structure due to cell growth and differentiation. The new individuals which are born from the eggs continue to grow till they become adults. In some animals, the young ones may look very different from the adults. Metamorphosis cycle has four stages: Egg, Larva, Pupa and Adult. Examples: Butterflies, moths, frogs, toads, etc.

question.content: How many arteries are there in an umbilical cord?

solution.content: Two. The umbilical cord is a tube that connects the mother with the baby in her womb during pregnancy. It normally contains two arteries (the umbilical arteries) and one vein (the umbilical vein).

question.content: _ is the ability of a single cell to produce a fertile, adult individual. .

solution.content: Totipotency. Pluripotency is defined as the capacity of individual cells to initiate all lineages of the mature organism. Cloning is a technique scientists use to make exact genetic copies of living things. A mutation occurs when a DNA gene is damaged or changed in such a way as to alter the genetic message carried by that gene.

question.content: The phenomenon whereby the female gamete undergoes development to form new organisms without fertilisation in some organisms like honey bees, some lizards and birds is called:

solution.content: Parthenogenesis is a form of reproduction in which an egg can develop into an embryo without being fertilized by a sperm. Budding or blastogenesis is a type of asexual reproduction in which a new organism develops from an outgrowth or bud due to cell division at one particular site. Apomixis refers to the formation of the plant from a seed without fertilization or normal sexual reproduction.

question.content: Which of the following is the primary sex organ in females?

solution.content: The ovary is the primary female reproductive organ in which the ova or eggs are produced, present in humans and other vertebrates as a pair. The fallopian tubes, also known as uterine tubes, oviducts or salpinges (singular salpinx), are paired tubes in the human female that stretch from the uterus to the ovaries. In mammals, the vagina is the elastic, muscular part of the female genital tract. In humans, it extends from the vestibule to the cervix. Reproduction in Plants

question.content: The reproduction process in which only a single parent is involved is called

solution.content: Asexual reproduction Observed in both multicellular and unicellular organisms and does not involve any kind of gamete fusion. Offspring are genetically similar to their parents. Different types: Binary Fission Cell divide (Archaea and Bacteria). Budding (Bacteria, yeast, corals, flatworms, Jellyfish and sea anemones). Fragmentation (Spirogyra, Planaria). Vegetative Propagation (Potato tubers, runners, onion). Sporogenesis (Plants, Algae, Fungi).

question.content: The innermost part of a flower is called the

solution.content: Pistil (the female reproductive part of a flower). It has three parts which are stigma, style, and ovary. Sepals (collectively called the calyx) are modified leaves that encase the developing flower. Petals (collectively known as the corolla) are modified leaves that surround the reproductive parts of flowers. Stamen is the male part of the flower. Generally, it is shaped like a bowling pin and is located in the flower's center. It consists of Anther and Filament. Stamen Anther LFilament Petal- Sepal -Stigma- -Style Pistil -Ovary-

question.content: Which of the following is not an asexual form of reproduction in plants?

solution.content: Pollination. Flowering plants reproduce sexually through a process called pollination. It is the act of transferring pollen grains from the male anther of a flower to the female stigma. The two types of pollination are self-pollination (if pollen is transferred to it from any flower of the same plant) and cross-pollination (if the pollen comes from a flower of a different plant).

question.content: Productivity of an ecosystem is composed of which of the following?

options.text: Net primary productivity and gross primary productivity

answer: Net primary productivity and gross primary productivity

solution.content: Net primary productivity and gross primary productivity. Gross primary productivity is the rate at which organic matter is produced through photosynthesis, while net primary productivity is the total amount of biomass accessible for heterotrophic use.

question.content: How do the red algae reproduce vegetatively?

solution.content: Fragmentation It is a type of asexual reproduction in which an organism simply breaks into individual pieces at maturity. These individual small pieces then grow to form a new organism, for example Spirogyra.

question.content: Which part of a flower is the sticky surface at the top of the pistil, it traps and holds the pollen?

solution.content: Stigma. It traps and holds the pollen. During the process of pollination, pollen moves from the male parts to the female parts i.e stigma where pollen germinates.

question.content: A type of asexual reproduction in which new plants are produced from roots, stems, leaves and buds are known as:

solution.content: Vegetative propagation. Layering is a technique of plant propagation where the new plant remains at least partially attached to the mother plant while forming new roots. Cell: Basic Unit of life

question.content: Which structural layer in some cell types is composed mainly of carbohydrates like cellulose, hemicellulose and lignin in the ratio 4: 3: 3 and some fatty substances like wax?

solution.content: Cell walls - They are found in most of the plant cells, bacteria, algae, fungi, and some archaea. The cell wall is a rigid semi-permeable structure made up of cellulose or chitin.

question.content: The primary function of which channel protein is to transport water across the cell membrane in response to the osmotic gradient created by active solute transport?

solution.content: Aquaporins. These are a family of small, integral membrane proteins that are expressed broadly throughout the animal and plant kingdoms. Mucins : Heavily O-glycosylated linear glycoproteins that are secreted by higher organisms to protect and lubricate epithelial cell surfaces. Transferrin: A blood plasma glycoprotein that plays a central role in iron metabolism and is responsible for ferric-ion delivery. Cupredoxins: Small proteins that contain type I copper centers. They function as electron transfer shuttles between proteins.

question.content: Most centrioles have a structure of triple microtubules, which are present in pairs and arranged orthogonally after duplication.

solution.content: 9 + 0. The centrioles form the basal body of cilia or flagella, and spindle fibres that give rise to spindle apparatus during cell division in animal cells. The central part of the proximal region of the centriole is also proteinaceous and called the hub, which is connected with tubules of the peripheral triplets by radial spokes made of protein. In animal cells, centrioles also form spindle apparatus during cell division.

question.content: Which is a reversible, fluorescent red, acidic dye used to stain cytoplasm, red blood cells, collagen and muscle fibres for histological examination?

solution.content: Eosin (the aniline dye) is an acid dye that stains cytoplasm, muscle, and connective tissues in various shades of pink and orange. Safranin is a lipophilic cationic dye which accumulates in mitochondria according to the inside negative potential in energised mitochondria. Alizarin (C14H8O4) is an organic compound that has been used throughout history as a prominent red dye, principally for dyeing textile fabrics. It was derived from the roots of plants of the madder genus.

question.content: Which cellular structure controls cell motility, adhesion, and polarity at interphase, and facilitates the organisation of spindle poles during mitosis ?

solution.content: Centrosomes Membrane free organelles that serve as main microtubule-organizing centers in distinct eukaryotic lineages. Peroxisomes Specialized for carrying out oxidative reactions using molecular oxygen. Lysosomes Membrane enclosed organelles that contain an array of enzymes capable of breaking down all types of biological polymers. Glyoxysomes - Specialized peroxisomes found in plants and also in filamentous fungi.

question.content: What is the percentage of proteins in the cell membrane?

solution.content: 40-60%. Cell membrane (plasma membrane) It separates the interior of the cell from the outside environment. It is composed primarily of fatty-acid-based lipids and proteins. The cell is the basic structural and functional unit of all forms of life. It was discovered by a British scientist, Robert Hooke in 1665.

question.content: What do you call the fluid matrix filling in the cell?

solution.content: Cytoplasm. It is composed of water, salts, and various organic molecules. Golgi bodies (Golgi apparatus) It helps process and package proteins and lipid molecules, especially proteins destined to be exported from the cell.

question.content: The main function of centriole is:

options.text: to maintain mineral composition in bacterial cell
to help plant cell for multiplication
to help cell division in animal cell
to maintain rigidity in plant cell

answer: to help cell division in animal cell

solution.content: Centrosome An organelle containing two cylindrical structures called centrioles. Centrioles form the basal body of cilia or flagella, and spindle fibres that give rise to spindle apparatus during cell division in animal cells. It plays a role in organizing microtubules that serve as the cell's skeletal system. They help determine the locations of the nucleus and other organelles within the cell.

question.content: During Which phase of the cell cycle does metabolic changes assemble the cytoplasmic material required for mitosis and cytokinesis?

solution.content: G2 phase. The different phases of a cell cycle include: Interphase (This phase includes the G1 phase, S phase and the G2 phase), M phase (This is the mitotic phase and is divided into prophase, metaphase, anaphase and telophase) and Cytokinesis (In this phase the cytoplasm of the cell divides). S phase Cell synthesises a complete copy of the DNA. M phase - Cell divides its copied DNA and cytoplasm to make two new cells. G1 phase First gap phase, the cell grows physically larger.

question.content: How big are red blood cells in diameter ?

solution.content: 7.5 um. Red blood cells (erythrocytes) - It is rich in hemoglobin, an iron rich molecule that can bind oxygen and also imparts red color to the blood. RBC is produced in the bone marrow (erythropoiesis process) and has a life cycle of 120 days. RBC is recycled by macrophages. RBC Disorders: Anemia (Lower than normal RBC), Polycythemia (Excess of RBC), Sickle Cell Disease (Genetic Disorder causes RBCs to take on a crescent shape), Thalassemia (Genetic blood disorders that result in abnormal hemoglobin production).

question.content: Which cell organelle appears as rounded or sausage-shaped structures under electron microscopy, measuring about 0.5 1.0 µm in diameter and 2-8 um in length?

solution.content: Mitochondria (Powerhouse of the cell). Lysosome It contains digestive enzymes. If the cell gets damaged, then lysosomes digest their own cell, hence Known as Suicide Bag of cell.

question.content: What is the length of a bacterial cell?

solution.content: 3 to 5 µm. Bacteria are single-celled microorganisms. Bacterial cell - Prokaryotic cells, lacking well - defined nuclei and membrane-bound organelles, and with chromosomes composed of a single closed DNA circle. Length of cells in organisms: Human 20-30 micrometres. Plants 10 to 100 micrometers.

question.content: What do you call a Glycocalyx that is a loose sheath type?

solution.content: Slime layer. It is a type of glycocalyx that is loosely organized and not firmly attached to the cellwall. It is a thin, diffuse layer of polysaccharides and proteins that surrounds some bacterial cells. The slime layer can help bacteria adhere to surfaces and protect them from dehydration. The glycocalyx is a dense, gel-like meshwork that surrounds the cell, constituting a physical barrier for any object to enter the cell.

question.content: Which process is sometimes called "reduction division" because it reduces the number of chromosomes to half the normal number to form sperm and eggs?

solution.content: Meiosis. The cell cycle is divided into two basic phases Interphase and M Phase (Mitosis phase). The M Phase represents the phase when the actual cell division or mitosis occurs and the interphase represents the phase between two successive M phases (Cytokinesis and Karyokinesis).

question.content: Which is the primary structural component responsible for most of the mechanical strength of the cell wall?

solution.content: Cellulose. Cell wall not only gives shape to the cell and protects the cell from mechanical damage and infection, it also helps in cell-to-cell interaction and provides a barrier to undesirable macromolecules. Algae have a cell wall, made of cellulose, galactans, mannans and minerals like calcium carbonate, while in other plants it consists of cellulose, hemicellulose, pectins and proteins.

question.content: By what name are the flat membrane-enclosed sacs present in the Golgi apparatus known?

solution.content: Cisternae It is a membrane-bound cell organelle consisting of a series of flattened membranous sacs that look like stacked pouches. Organelles present in cells- Nucleus, Endoplasmic Reticulum, Mitochondria, Centriole, Ribosome, Vacuole, Lysosome.

question.content: Which cell found in the bone marrow acts as a repair system for the body?

solution.content: Stem cells Unspecialised cells which divide to produce two daughter cells, one of which remains a stem cell and the other one becomes differentiated. The major sources of stem cells are embryos and adult tissues (adult stem cells). Stem cells are characterised into three types depending on their potency: Unipotent cells, pluripotent cells and multipotent cells.

question.content: During cell division, the formation of a new cell wall is followed by the accumulation of:

solution.content: Phragmoplast is a plant cell specialized cylindrical structure formed during late cytokinesis. Periplasm - The space is the area between the cell wall and the plasma membrane. The term Protoplast was introduced by Hanstein. It refers to the entire cell, excluding the cell wall. The Peristome is a teeth-like projection that surrounds the mouth of the capsule in most of the members of Bryidae (Mosses) of bryophytes.

question.content: Which part of a cell converts nutrients into energy?

solution.content: Mitochondria Double membrane-bound cell organelles present in most eukaryotic organisms (such as animals, plants and fungi). Chromosome A thread like microscopic structure formed by coiling of DNA packaged with protein containing all genetic material of an organism.

question.content: Which cell analysis technique is used to rapidly analyse single cells or particles as they flow through single or multiple lasers while suspended in a buffered salt-based solution?

solution.content: Flow cytometryIt is a laser-based technique used to detect and analyze the chemical and physical characteristics of cells or particles, It is to evaluate bone marrow, peripheral blood and other fluids in your body. Mass spectroscopy Used to identify and quantify molecules by measuring their mass-to-charge ratio. Electrochemical analysis - Used to measure the electrical properties of cells or particles. Multiple displacement amplification Used to amplify DNA.

question.content: The division of cytoplasm is known as:

solution.content: Cytokinesis: It is a physical process which divides the cytoplasm of a parental cell into two daughter cells. Karyokinesis: Division of the nucleus during mitosis or meiosis. Cytoskeleton: It is a network of fibres forming the eukaryotic cells, prokaryotic cells and archaeans. Cytosol: The fluid in which organelles of the cell reside. The primary component of cytosol is water.

question.content: Which of the following cell organelles can make copies of themselves?

solution.content: Mitochondria (Powerhouse of cells). Vacuole A membrane-bound cell organelle. In animal cells, vacuoles are generally small and help sequester waste products.

question.content: Which type of haploid unicellular eukaryote cells has a diameter of ~10 µm, and about half of their volume is occupied by cup-shaped chloroplasts?

solution.content: Chlamydomonas: Single -celled green algae found in both freshwater and marine habitats. It reproduces asexually by zoospores, hypnospores. Hydrodictyon (water net): green algae, found in freshwater. Ulva (sea lettuce): Green algae, found in marine environments. Oedogonium : Green algae, found in freshwater ponds, streams, and even in some terrestrial environments with high humidity.

question.content: Which cell organelles are known as cell's post office?

solution.content: Golgi apparatus. It is responsible for processing and packaging proteins and lipid molecules, particularly those destined for export. Nucleus - The membrane enclosed organelle within a cell that contains the chromosomes. Ribosome An intracellular structure composed of RNA and protein, responsible for protein synthesis within the cell.

question.content: Which of the following cells are found in the liver of mammals?

solution.content: Kupffer cells. They are resident liver macrophages and maintain liver functions. They are the first innate immune cells and protect the liver from bacterial infections. Purkinje cells - They are a unique type of neuron, specific to the cerebellar cortex. Microglia cells are resident cells of the brain that regulate brain development, maintenance of neuronal networks, and injury repair. Sensory cells - They occur in specialized organs such as the eyes, ears, nose, and mouth, as well as internal organs.

question.content: Which of the following cell organelles is made up of ribosomal RNA and protein?

solution.content: Ribosome. Cell is the structural and functional unit of all living organisms. It has three main parts - Cell membrane, Cytoplasm organelles, and Nucleus.

question.content: In cells, proteins are synthesized in

solution.content: Ribosome These are non - membrane bound organelles found in all cells (eukaryotic as well as prokaryotic). Animal cells contain a non - membrane -bound organelle called centrosome which helps in cell division.

question.content: Mitochondria is not found in

solution.content: Bacteria (Discovered by Leeuwenhoek (father of microbiology). Mitochondria generates most of the chemical energy needed to power the cell's biochemical reactions and the chemical energy produced by the mitochondria is stored in a small molecule called adenosine triphosphate (ATP). Mitochondria contain their own small chromosomes (mitochondrial DNA or mtDNA).

question.content: In a plant, _ is present in the middle lamella, primary cell and secondary walls and accumulates in the initial stages of development during cell expansion.

solution.content: Pectin (polysaccharide) soluble fibre found in fruits. Chitin A A long chain polymer of N -acetylglucosamine, an amide derivative of glucose, forms a long chain polymer. Present in cell walls and septa of all pathogenic fungi and cyst walls of pathogenic amoebae. Gelatin A food ingredient found in soups, broths, sauces, gummy candies, marshmallows, cosmetics, and medications. Alginate Naturally occurring anionic polymer typically obtained from brown seaweed.

question.content: Select the correct statement.

options.text: Mitochondria and nucleus are found in bacteria.
Ribosomes, mitochondria and lysosomes are found in animal cells.
Chloroplast, ribosomes and nucleus are present in fungal cells.
Mitochondria and nucleus are absent in plant cells.

answer: Ribosomes, mitochondria and lysosomes are found in animal cells.

solution.content: Bacteria do not have a nucleus or membrane-bound organelles. They have ribosomes. Fungal cells have ribosomes and a nucleus. They also have other organelles like endoplasmic reticulum, mitochondria, ribosomes, Golgi apparatus and vacuoles. Plant cells have ribosomes (Responsible for protein synthesis) mitochondria, nucleus, and chloroplasts (responsible for photosynthesis).

question.content: Which of the following statements is correct regarding cell membrane? I. The membrane is selectively permeable to some molecules present on either side of it. II. Water may also move across this membrane from lower to higher concentration.

solution.content: Only 1. Cell membrane (outermost covering of the cell). Function of the plasma membrane - Transport of molecules across it. Many molecules can move actively across the membrane without any requirement of energy and this type of transport is called passive transport. Water may also move across this membrane from higher to lower concentration, and the movement of water by diffusion is known as osmosis.

question.content: Which form of leucoplast specialises in oil synthesis and storage and is mainly found in the layer of cells in pollen grains that develop pollen grains?

solution.content: Elaioplasts These are plastids that are specialized in oil synthesis and found primarily in the layer of cells. Gerontoplasts - Type of plastid formed during leaf senescence (deterioration with age), Derived from Chloroplasts. Proteinoplasts are specialized organelles found in plant cells. Chloroplasts are organelle that contains the photosynthetic pigment chlorophyll that captures sunlight and converts it into useful energy, Found in green plants and algaе.

question.content: Which cells, also called neurilemma cells, are the main glial cells in the PNS and play an essential role in the survival and functions of neurons?

solution.content: Schwann cells. Peripheral Nervous System - Part of your nervous system that lies outside the brain and spinal cord. Central nervous system - Includes two organs, the brain and spinal cord. Bipolar cells One of the main retinal interneurons that provide the main pathways from photoreceptors to ganglion cells.

question.content: Which of the following is found in plant cells only?

solution.content: Cell wall (outermost cover of plant cells). Plant cells possess Cell walls, Plastid and a large central vacuole. Nucleolus - A spherical structure found in the cell's nucleus. Its primary function is to produce and assemble the cell's ribosomes.

question.content: Which cell organelle containing millions of membrane-bound ribosomes is involved in the production, folding. quality control and dispatch of certain proteins?

solution.content: Rough endoplasmic reticulum. Peroxisome - A cell organelle responsible for various metabolic functions, including the breakdown of fatty acids and the detoxification of harmful substances.

question.content: The cells having well-organized nuclei with a nuclear membrane are designated as.

solution.content: Eukaryotic cells - Larger and more complex than prokaryotic cells. These possess a well-defined nucleus, enclosed within a nuclear membrane, and contain various membrane-bound organelles such as mitochondria, endoplasmic reticulum, Golgi apparatus, and others.

question.content: Which component of the cell contains the hereditary material of the cell, the DNA?

solution.content: Nucleus (Discovered by Robert Brown) - It is a membrane - bound organelle found in eukaryotic cells. It contains the cell's genetic material, including DNA, which carries the instructions for cell function and inheritance. Deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) - Discovered by James Watson and Francis Crick.

question.content: Cells were first observed in cork by in 1665.

solution.content: Robert Hooke. Edward Jenner Discovered the smallpox vaccine in 1796. Theophrastus The father of botany. Anton van Leeuwenhoek (Father of Microbiology) He discovered protists and bacteria.

question.content: Which of the following is NOT one of the three main parts of the cell?

solution.content: Vacuole. Cell - The structural and fundamental unit of life. Robert Hooke discovered cells. Types of cell - Prokaryotes and Eukaryotes.

question.content: What is the jelly-like substance between the nucleus and the cell membrane called?

solution.content: Cytoplasm. It is the main area for all the activities taking place inside a cell. It is made of water, salts and proteins. Plasma is the fluid that makes up the blood and other bodily fluids.

question.content: Which component of the cell organelles principally performs the function of packaging materials, to be delivered either to the intra-cellular targets or secreted outside the cell?

solution.content: Golgi Apparatus (Golgi complex or Golgi body).

question.content: What is the major function of a cell wall?

options.text: It works as a storage for material
It provides shape and rigidity to the cell
It is responsible for cell division
It helps in synthesis of carbohydrate

answer: It provides shape and rigidity to the cell

solution.content: The cell wall in plants is composed mainly of cellulose and contains three layers in many plants. The three layers are the middle lamella, primary cell wall, and secondary cell wall. It is only found in Plant Cell.

question.content: The cells having nuclear material without a nuclear membrane are termed as_

solution.content: Prokaryotic cells (undefined nucleus and unicellular), example- bacteria and archaea etc. Cheek cell - An animal cell consists of a cell membrane and nucleus. Onion cell- It is a multicellular plant cell that has a cell wall (made up of cellulose), cell membrane, cytoplasm, nucleus and vacuole.

question.content: Which of the following is characteristic of a plant cell?

solution.content: Cell wall is present. Plant cells have a rigid cell wall that surrounds the cell membrane. This cell wall provides structural support and protection for the cell. Animal cells do not have a cell wall. Animal cells have lysosomes which are organelles that contain enzymes that break down cellular waste while Plant cells do not have lysosomes.

question.content: Which among the following statements is incorrect?

options.text: Cell walls are present in animals.
Cell membrane is also called the plasma membrane.
Chromosomes are composed of DNA and Protein.
Mitochondria are known as the powerhouse of the cell.

answer: Cell walls are present in animals.

solution.content: Plant cell wall - An elaborate extracellular matrix that encloses each cell in a plant.

question.content: Cytology is the study of

solution.content: Cells. Genetics- The scientific study of genes and heredity. Histology The study of tissues. Anatomy The identification and description of the structures of living things.

question.content: Plant cell have a big central unlike a number of small_ in animal cells.

solution.content: Vacuole, vacuoles. Plant cells Eukaryotic cells that vary in several fundamental factors from other eukaryotic organisms. It is rectangular and comparatively larger than the animal cell. Tissue - A group of cells with similar structure and function. It forms a cellular organizational level, intermediate between the cells and organ system.

question.content: Which among the following is the structural and fundamental unit of life?

solution.content: Cell. Enzymes are proteins that help to speed up chemical reactions in the body. Hormones - Chemical substances that act like messenger molecules in the body.

question.content: Which of the following is a complex permanent plant tissue?  (Afternoon

solution.content: XylemIt is a complex permanent tissue found in vascular plants. It is responsible for conducting water, minerals, and nutrients from the roots to the other parts of the plant. Xylem and Phloem are the Complex Permanent tissues.

question.content: Which cell organelles help intercellular digestion and are known the "Suicidal bags" of the cell?

solution.content: Lysosome. Chloroplast A type of membrane-bound organelle known as a plastid that conducts photosynthesis mostly in plant and algal cells.

question.content: At high doses, kills cancer cells or slows their growth by damaging their DNA. Cancer cells whose DNA is damaged beyond repair, stop dividing or die. When the damaged cells die, they are broken down and removed by the body.

solution.content: Radiation therapy. The X-ray generating methodology is applied to cancer therapy. X-rays discovered in 1895 by W. C. Roentgen. Types of radiation therapy: 1. External beam radiation therapy comes from a machine to deliver radiation. 2. Internal radiation therapy uses implants or drugs to deliver radiation inside the body.

question.content: Which of the following statements is NOT correct regarding the prokaryotic cell?

options.text: They have only very small ribosomes as organelles
Membrane bound cell organelles are present
Their chromosomes are composed of only nucleic acid.
Their size is generally in the range of 1-10 µm

answer: Membrane bound cell organelles are present

solution.content: Membrane bound cell organelles are present.

question.content: is the chemical process in which different types of chemical reactions are involved in controlling the living state of the cells in an organism.

solution.content: Metabolism. The circulatory system is the "transportation system" for the body, and blood serves as the transport vehicle. Respiration - Process in which organisms exchange gases between their body cells and the environment. Excretion Process by which animals rid themselves of waste products and of the nitrogenous by-products of metabolism.

question.content: In Golgi apparatus, the maturing face is:

solution.content: Concave. The Golgi cisternae are concentrically arranged near the nucleus with distinct convex cis or the forming face and concave, trans or the maturing face. The Golgi apparatus (discovered by Camillo Golgi in 1898) is located close to the nucleus and can be very large in secretory cells, where it fills almost the complete cytoplasm.

question.content: What is the outermost layer found in the cell envelope of the bacterial cell called?

solution.content: Glycocalyx. It is a network of polysaccharides attached to the cell wall.

question.content: There are_ main types of cell division.

solution.content: 2. Types Mitosis: The process in which cells use to make exact replicas of themselves. Mitosis is observed in almost all the body's cells, including eyes, skin, hair, and muscle cells. Meiosis: In this type of cell division, sperm or egg cells are produced instead of identical daughter cells as in mitosis. not have a true nucleus and membrane-bound organelles single celled microorganisms. Examples Bacteria and Archaea, Mycoplasma (Pleuropneumonia-like organism, a genus of bacteria), Blue-green algae (cyanobacteria).

question.content: A group of ribosomes attached to mRNA is known as

solution.content: Polysomes. They include a piece of the genetic code that is translated by each ribosome and are employed in the synthesis of numerous copies of the same polypeptide. Polypeptide short chains of amino acids linked by peptide bonds. Long chains of amino acids are called proteins. Polymer materials made of long, repeating chains of molecules. Monomer - A molecule that forms the basic unit for polymers. Example - Sugar is a monomer of polymers like glycogen, starch, and cellulose.

options.text: Cell wall of a plant cell is made up of cellulose. i.Mitochondria a. Protein synthesis ii. Ribosomes b. Regulation of activity of a cell iii. Nucleus c. Digestive system of a cell iv. Lysosomes d. Energy generation SSC CGL

A plant cell usually contains a large vacuole.

solution.content: Sperm. question.content: An undifferentiated layer, is present in between the ectoderm and the endoderm.

solution.content: Mesoglea. Coelenterata and Ctenophora show the scattered pouches in between ectoderm and endoderm. Animals in which the body cavity is absent are called acoelomates, such as Platyhelminthes.

question.content: What happens to the decomposition rate when detritus is rich in lignin and chitin?

solution.content: It is slower. Decomposition is faster if nitrogen and water soluble substances are present.

question.content: Identify the function of plasmid DNA.

options.text: None of the given options are correct
To confer certain unique phenotypic characters to bacteria
To help in the formation of rRNA

answer: To confer certain unique phenotypic characters to bacteria

solution.content: A plasmid is a small, circular, double-stranded DNA molecule that is distinct from a cell's chromosomal DNA. Plasmids naturally exist in bacterial cells, and they also occur in some eukaryotes. Often, the genes carried in plasmids provide bacteria with genetic advantages, such as antibiotic resistance.

question.content: is a group of cells similar in structure and function.

solution.content: Tissues (French word 'tissue means to weave). There are 4 basic types of tissue: connective tissue, epithelial tissue, muscle tissue, and nervous tissue.

question.content: Match Column-A with Column-B Column-A i. GI ii. S iii. G2 iv. M Column-B a. Cell synthesises a complete copy of the DNA b. First gap phase, the cell grows physically larger c. d. Cell begins to reorganise its contents in preparation for mitosis Cell divides its copied DNA and cytoplasm to make two new cells

solution.content: i-b, ii-a, iii-c, iv-d.

options.text: The ribosomes of a polysome translate the mRNA into proteins.

question.content: Which of the following is a plant tissue? I. Meristematic tissue II. Permanent tissue

solution.content: Meristematic tissues are cells or groups of cells that have the ability to divide. The tissues that are completely grown and have lost the ability to divide are known as Permanent tissues. Types of Plant Tissue Meristematic Tissue (Apical, Intercalary, Lateral) and Permanent Tissue {Simple (Parenchyma, Collenchyma, Sclerenchyma), Complex (Xylem and Phloem)}.

question.content: Cells of meristematic tissue lack

solution.content: Vacuoles. They are dividing rigorously so they need not store food or waste products.

question.content: Which of the following is NOTa type of chromosome, on the basis of the location of the centromere?

solution.content: Lophocentric. Chromosomes are bundles of tightly coiled DNA located within the nucleus of almost every cell in our body. Depending on the position of the centromere, chromosomes are categorized into the following types: Metacentric, Telocentric, Acrocentric, Submetacentric.

question.content: Which cell organelle is an overlapping membranous sac with ER-like thickness that helps in processing and packaging protein and lipid molecules, especially stable proteins?

question.content: Amoeba acquires its food through the process of _

solution.content: Endocytosis is a general term describing a process by which cells absorb external material by engulfing it with the cell membrane. Exocytosis is the process by which cells move materials from within the cell into the extracellular fluid. Diffusion is the movement of molecules from an area of high concentration of the molecules to an area with a lower concentration.

question.content: Which of the following statements is correct about endoplasmic reticulum? I. It is a large network of membrane bound tubes and sheets. II. It is similar in structure to the plasma membrane.

solution.content: Both and II. The endoplasmic reticulum can either be smooth or rough, and in general its function is to produce proteins for the rest of the cell to function. Endoplasmic Reticulum is a network of membranous tubules present within the cytoplasm of a eukaryotic cell.

question.content: _is known as the energy currency of the cell.

ADP is adenosine diphosphate and contains only two phosphate groups. DNA, or deoxyribonucleic acid, is the hereditary material in humans and almost all other organisms. Ribonucleic acid (RNA) is a nucleic acid present in all living cells.

question.content: Which of the following are situated in the nucleus of a cell?

The cytoplasm and nucleus are enclosed within the cell membrane. also called the plasma membrane
The membrane separates ribosomes and mitochondria of a cell
The plasma membrane does not allow inward movement of the substance

solution.content: Centrosome is a cellular structure involved in the process of cell division.

question.content: What is the role of ribosomes of a polysome?

solution.content: A polysome is a group of ribosomes bound to an mRNA molecule like "beads" on a "thread". It consists of a complex of an mRNA molecule and two or more ribosomes that act to translate mRNA instructions into polypeptides.

question.content: Which of the following is an example of active transport?

solution.content: Sodium-potassium pump present on the cell membrane, which transports 3 sodium ions outside and 2 potassium ions inside of the cell per АТР. Active transport (uphill transport) transports substances against the concentration gradient from lower to higher concentration. Passive transport (Glucose transporters) are a wide group of membrane proteins that facilitate the transport of glucose across the plasma membrane.

solution.content: White blood cells. They are part of the body's immune system. They help the body fight infection and other diseases. Types of white blood cells are granulocytes (neutrophils, eosinophils, and basophils), monocytes, and lymphocytes (T cells and B cells).

question.content: The blood platelets are also known as

solution.content: Thrombocytes. They are cell fragments found in blood and spleen produced from megakaryocytes (special cells in the bone marrow). solution.content: Iron. Haemoglobin (Hb): It is a protein in red blood cells that binds to oxygen, enabling its transport throughout the body, crucial for oxygen delivery to tissues and organs. In its iron-bound state, haemoglobin gives blood its red colour.

question.content: glands release tears from our eyes.

solution.content: Both I and II. The lungs and respiratory system allows us to breathe. They bring oxygen into our bodies (called inspiration, or inhalation) and send carbon dioxide out (called expiration, or exhalation). This exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide is called respiration.

solution.content: 4.4%. Composition of exhaled air: nitrogen (78%) oxygen (17%) carbon dioxide (4%) other gases (1%). Inhaled air is by volume: 78% nitrogen, 20.95% oxygen and small amounts of other gases including argon, carbon dioxide, neon, helium, and hydrogen.
